title: 105_hr2596
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Agricultural Products Market Access Act of 1997". Congress finds that the export of agricultural products is crucial for the US economy, with agriculture being a significant contributor to the trade balance. Increasing agricultural exports will boost farm income, support family farms, and benefit rural communities. The denial of fair market access hinders US agricultural exports, leading to a $4.7 billion annual loss. This Act aims to address foreign unfair trade practices and promote fair trade. The Act aims to ensure fair market access for US agricultural exports and promote free and fair trade in agricultural products. SEC. 183 of the Trade Act of 1974 identifies countries that deny market access for agricultural products. The Trade Act of 1974, in section 183, requires the United States Trade Representative to identify foreign countries that restrict market access for US agricultural products based on unfair standards or lack of public health justification. Priority foreign countries are determined by the Trade Representative within 30 days of the annual report submission to Congressional committees. The Trade Act of 1974 mandates the identification of priority foreign countries that restrict market access for US agricultural products based on unfair standards. The Trade Representative must identify countries engaging in egregious acts that deny fair market access, with the greatest adverse impact on US products, and not actively negotiating or making progress. The Trade Representative must identify priority foreign countries restricting market access for US agricultural products based on unfair standards. Consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture and other relevant government officials is required, considering information from various sources and interested parties. The Trade Representative identifies foreign countries restricting market access for US agricultural products based on unfair standards. This is done by considering reports and petitions, ensuring a factual basis for denial of fair market access. Historical factors are also taken into account in this process. The Trade Representative can revoke or identify foreign countries as priority foreign countries based on market access issues for US agricultural products. The Trade Representative must provide detailed explanations for revocations and identify priority foreign countries in semiannual reports to Congress. A foreign country denies fair market access by violating international agreements or creating discriminatory trade barriers. The Trade Representative is required to publish this information. The Trade Representative must publish a list of foreign countries identified for trade actions and provide annual reports to Congress on actions taken to achieve fair market access for US agricultural products. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include a new item after section 182 in the table of contents. SEC. 4. INVESTIGATIONS. Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to require investigations related to market access for agricultural products. Includes a conforming amendment concerning intellectual property rights. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZED ACTIONS BY UNITED STATES TRADE REPRESENTATIVE. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZED ACTIONS BY UNITED STATES TRADE REPRESENTATIVE. Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to allow the United States Trade Representative to request the Secretary of Agriculture to review certifications for facilities in countries exporting meat and agricultural products to the United States.
